content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given the rules of the game, it seems that choosing either R or B doesn't necessarily provide an advantage for one player over the other, as the payoffs are symmetric. However, since there are 75 rounds, it suggests a strategic long-term approach rather than a random choice.

In this type of game, a strategy like "Tit for Tat" might be employed to encourage cooperation and mimic the behavior of the opponent. This strategy involves starting with a cooperative move (R), and then choosing the same action as your opponent in the following rounds. If the opponent chooses B, you will respond with B until they switch back to R.

By doing this, you ensure that you both earn 45$ more often than earning 0$, and you encourage cooperation from your anonymous partner. However, since there is no way of knowing if the opponent will adopt a similar strategy or not, it remains a risky yet potentially beneficial choice.

Taking all these factors into account, I would choose R as my first move (R{) to start cooperating and set a pattern for the game, hoping that my opponent will reciprocate. But ultimately, whether or not this strategy leads to the best outcome depends on the actions of your anonymous partner throughout the game.
